fields.summary: euca-register throws 'Request timed out' error and register an image

comments.body:
Although it timed out it sounds like it ended up getting registered. Since I issue register twice and the second call reported successful, describe images reports the image being registered twice:

{code}
[root@h-29 ~]# euca-describe-images 
IMAGE	eki-8A3A392B	tmpxjqk5ayt3q/vmlinuz-3.2.0-23-virtual.manifest.xml	275131540757	available	private	i386	kernel				instance-store		
IMAGE	emi-15F53874	tmpph2js30lbt/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml	275131540757	available	public	i386	machine	eki-8A3A392B	eri-8E09358F		instance-store		
IMAGE	emi-C3DE36A9	windows/windowsserver2003r2_ent_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml	275131540757	available	private	x86_64	machine			windows	instance-store		
IMAGE	emi-FA7C3A69	windows/windowsserver2003r2_ent_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml	275131540757	available	private	x86_64	machine			windows	instance-store		
IMAGE	eri-8E09358F	tmpkgc8d1hzaa/initrd.img-3.2.0-23-virtual.manifest.xml	275131540757	available	private	i386	ramdisk				instance-store		
{code}

Closed EUCA-7505 in order to track here. 
Note that the 3 people who have recently reported this were using Windows images. The images are larger, take longer, more load on the Walrus, etc.. 
Cheers, 
-M

The timeout takes place in the tool. The default timeout is 30 seconds and changing the default has been controversial in the past. Any user can override the default with a 'timeout' setting for euca2ools. So that is a workaround.

The interesting question is why would a larger image take longer to register than a smaller one? That seems wrong and that seems like the root of this problem. Perhaps [~neil] or [~zhill] could speculate?

That's euca-register giving up on its request after thirty seconds without a response.  If your cloud happens to misbehave in this way frequently you can configure a different timeout with a {{timeout}} option.  For the gory details, have a look at the euca2ools user guide.

What reason could {{RegisterImage}} possibly have for taking more time based on image size?  The XML file doesn't get _that_ much longer.

During registration the CLC sends a "CacheImage" request to Walrus to try to initiate caching/decryption of the image. It looks like while that is intended to be a fully asynchronous call, the actual decryption phase of the image is invoked synchronously with the "register" call. The full unbundling is asynchronous but the decryption is on the synchronous path, it appears. That should definitely not be the case. For small images that decryption is quick, but for larger images it can take a while.

The fix is to make the CacheImage operation in WalrusImageManager a fully async operation.
Thanks, [~zhill], that makes sense. At this point, I would like the services team to consider whether or not to fix this one for 3.4.
[~dmitrii] this one falls in [~neil] 's court.  Reassigning to [~neil]

The fix should be to change: AsyncRequests.sendSync() to AsyncRequests.dispatch().

So I think this is a one-liner unless there are some other semantic assumptions made that require the synchronous call. I can't think of any on the registration path. I don't think registration requires all of the checks on the manifest that are done on the Walrus side during that sync call.

I looked at it some more and I think that the reason the call is synchronous is that it also verifies that the bucket and manifest object exist and have proper permissions. That is required to be synchronous on the registration path. That means that an asycn message is not sufficient unless we also include a couple of sync calls to Walrus to verify the bucket/object as well or else modify the CacheImage operation to not do the decrypt synchronously.
After consulting with [~decker] and [~dmitrii] we concluded that the change to dispatch() from sendSync() is the proper one and should not impact the semantics of the registration.
Fix is in testing now. Will do regular regression test and also run windows images to verify fix.

Time to register with fix:
{code}
[root@c-32 ~]# time euca-register -n Windows2003QAImage -d Standard_QA_Img -a x86_64 images/windowsserver2003r2_ent_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml
IMAGE	emi-F2CF3CCE

real	0m0.412s
user	0m0.110s
sys	0m0.018s
{code}

Time without fix (but on a different setup) with same exact image:
{code}
[root@d-01 ~]# euca-upload-bundle -m /var/tmp/bundle-EdVlFU/windowsserver2003r2_ent_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml -b zhill_images^C
[root@d-01 ~]# time euca-register zhill_images/windowsserver2003r2_ent_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml -n zhillWindows03Img -d Windows2k3_QA_img -a x86_64
IMAGE	emi-2124374E

real	0m23.067s
user	0m0.112s
sys	0m0.021s
[root@d-01 ~]#
{code}

Eucalyptus Repo Commit: 4e8dd0033e80c5a1ef60020ffcc6a328562e4213
Internal Commit: 5a424f6d081589225cc19f9f7cf2354bb1e22aec

Passed euca-sequence-3.3-dns with flying colors.
Tested with the windows QA image and registration took < 1sec compared to a non-fixed system where registration of the same image took 23s.

Regression potential/Risk: registration of invalid or corrupted images is possible that would have resulted in a registration error previously, but those errors were not AWS-spec anyway. Image integrity is not supposed to be checked at registration time.

Churn tests for lots of large images should be sufficient as well. The fix only addresses the RegisterImage operation on the CLC, so the risk is limited.

Registered about 10 windows images ranging in sizes from 13-16 gigs. Never saw the registration take more than ~1 second to return with an EMI. Images ran from these EMIs in kvm and vmware were good. 

GIT_HASH	fc873b8e55979ffb0e1e3d2a63971623af01e798

{code}
[root@b-02 ~]# time euca-register windows8/windows2008_8_21_12.img.manifest.xml -d windows8 --kernel windows -nwindows82
IMAGE	emi-80B6373C

real	0m0.964s
user	0m0.112s
sys	0m0.022s
[root@b-02 ~]# time euca-register windows8/windows2008_8_21_12.img.manifest.xml -d windows8 --kernel windows -nwindows83
IMAGE	emi-B94D3BD6

real	0m0.804s
user	0m0.108s
sys	0m0.021s
{code}
